{{Klausur}}, {{Aufgabe}}
(No official solution released, answers are not verified!)

{{Frage}}

{{Optionen}}

fields:
Definition: {{c1::Pervasive Computing}}

{{c1::Pervasive Computing}}, also called {{c2::Ubiquitous Computing}}, is the {{c3::growing trend of embedding computational capability (e.g. microprocessors) into everyday objects}} to {{c4::make them effectively communicate and perform useful tasks}} in a way that {{c5::minimizes the end user's need to interact with computers as computers}}.

Definition: {{c1::Mensch-Maschine-Interaktion / Human-Computer-Interaction}}

{{c1::Mensch-Maschine-Interaktion / Human-Computer-Interaction}} studies the {{c2::design and use of computer technology}}, focused on the {{c3::interfaces between humans/users and computers}}. It is an important part of {{c4::Pervasive/Ubiquitous Computing}}.

Definition: {{c1::PACT}}

{{c1::PACT}} is a {{c2::HCI design framework}} that focuses on {{c3::People undertaking Activities in Contexts using Technologies}}.

The two classes/times for studies and evaluation of HCI are {{c1::formative}}, i.e. {{c2::at the beginning to inform about context}} and {{c1::summative}}, i.e. {{c2::afterwards to judge the impact of the design}}.
(a summative evaluation can be a formative one for the next step)

The four W's of iterative design and evaluation are:
1. {{c1::Why}}, i.e. {{c1::the study question}}, e.g. {{c1::does the user like the product?}}
2. {{c2::What}}, e.g. {{c2::a conceptual model, an early prototype, human behavior}}
3. {{c3::Where}}, i.e. {{c3::in nature or in a laboratory setting}}
4. {{c4::When}}, i.e. {{c4::formative vs. summative}}
The three study measures are {{c1::effectiveness}}, {{c1::efficiency}} and {{c1::satisfaction}}.

The four different classes of evaluation are:
1. {{c1::Result Type ("why")}}, i.e. {{c1::subjective vs. objective}} and {{c1::quantitative (numbers) vs. qualitative (text)}}
2. {{c2::Evaluation Partner ("what")}}, i.e. {{c2::user vs. expert}}
3. {{c3::Setting ("where")}}, i.e. {{c3::natural vs. controlled settings}}
4. {{c4::Evaluation Time ("when")}}, i.e. {{c4::inspective vs. retrospective}} and {{c4::short-term vs. long-term}}

The five key issues of data recording are:
1. {{c1::Setting Goals}}, i.e. {{c1::how the data will be analyzed once collected}}
2. {{c2::Identifying Participants}}, i.e. {{c2::deciding who to gather data from}}
3. {{c3::Relationships with Participants}}, i.e. {{c3::clear and professional with informed consent}}
4. {{c4::Triangulation}}, i.e. {{c4::collecting multiple data types to look at the data from different perspectives}}
5. {{c5::Pilot Studies}}, i.e. {{c5::small trials of the main study}}

The three types of interviews are:
1. {{c1::Structured Interviews}}, i.e. {{c1::strictly following precise, pre-developed questions}}
2. {{c2::Semi-Structured Interviews}}, i.e. {{c2::a structured part + "open" questions ("tell me your ideas on...")}}
3. {{c3::Unstructured Interviews}}
A commonly used questionnaire scale is the {{c1::Likert Scale}}.

The five steps when running an interview are:
1. {{c1::Introduction}}, i.e. {{c1::introducing yourself, explaining the goals of the interview, getting consent}}
2. {{c2::Warm-up}}, i.e. {{c2::easy first questions}}
3. {{c3::Main Body}}, i.e. {{c3::the main questions in logical order}}
4. {{c4::Cool-Off}}, i.e. {{c4::easy questions to defuse tension}}
5. {{c5::Closure}}, i.e. {{c5::thanking the interviewee and signaling the end}}

The {{c1::System Usability Scale (SUS)}} is a {{c2::subjective, quick and dirty usability measurement standard}}.

Benefits:
- {{c3::Easy scale (Likert)}}
- {{c3::Useful in small sample sizes}}
- {{c3::Decent validity}}

Restrictions:
- {{c4::Score between 0-100 suggests percentages, even though they're not}}
- {{c4::Not diagnostic, just to classify, inconclusive for specific problems}}

The {{c1::Think Aloud}} technique serves the direct observation of someone, preferably a {{c2::non-expert}}, using an application while {{c3::constantly explaining what he/she is thinking}}.

It can be used to {{c4::categorize and solve obvious issues}} and {{c4::draw general conclusions}} about the application.
The {{c1::Experience Sampling Methodology (ESM)}} is a study method where participants are asked to {{c2::fill out short questionnaires at various points throughout the day}}.

Sampling strategies for selecting participants:
1. {{c1::Random Sampling}}, i.e. {{c1::everyone has equal probability of being selected}}
2. {{c2::Systematic Sampling}}, i.e. {{c2::selection based on predefined criteria}}, e.g. {{c2::first come first serve}}
3. {{c3::Stratified Sampling}}, i.e. {{c3::controlled randomness by selecting randomly from different strata}}, e.g. {{c3::50/50 male/female, random selection within male and female subgroups}}
4. {{c4::Samples of Convenience}}, i.e. {{c4::volunteer-based}}

Rule of thumb for estimating the percentage of issues found by \(n\) study participants when the average percentage of found issues across all participants is \(p\):

{{c1::\[1 - (1 - p)^n\]}}
To mitigate the effect of the task order on the results, the tasks are {{c1::rescheduled for each participant}}, e.g. using the {{c2::Latin Square}}.
(this might not be possible if tasks depend on each other, or might be unnecessary if tasks are unrelated)

{{c1::Heuristic Evaluations}} can be used when {{c2::no regular users/only experts are available}} to test the design of a system.

Key issues in this case are {{c3::the expenses of hiring experts}}, {{c3::overlooking important issues}}, {{c3::mostly catching trivial issues}} and {{c3::the experts' biases}}.

The three types of attention in human information processing (HIP):
1. {{c1::Selective Attention}}, i.e. {{c1::willingly selecting the focus}}
2. {{c2::Focused Attention}}, i.e. {{c2::responding to external events}}
3. {{c3::Divided Attention}}, i.e. {{c3::simultaneously focusing on different events}}

{{c1::Vigilance}} describes the ability to {{c2::detect intermittent, unpredictable and infrequent signals over a long period of time}}, e.g. in the case of providing {{c3::quality control at an assembly line}}.

The six vigilance paradigms:

1. {{c1::Free-Response Paradigm}}
\(\rightarrow\) {{c1::a target event occurs at any time, non-events are undefined}}, e.g. {{c1::power plant monitor supervision}}

2. {{c2::Inspection Paradigm}}
\(\rightarrow\) {{c2::events occur at fairly regular intervals, some are events, most are non-targets}}, e.g. {{c2::quality control}}

3. {{c3::Successive Vigilance Paradigm}}
\(\rightarrow\) {{c3::the target stimulus has to be remembered and successive events have to be compared}}, e.g. {{c3::detect of a color is darker than the initial one}}

4. {{c4::Simultaneous Vigilance Paradigm}}
\(\rightarrow\) {{c4::all events needed for discrimination are present at the same time}}, e.g. {{c4::comparing many types of garment to a standard piece of fabric}}

5. {{c5::Sensory Vigilance Paradigm}}
\(\rightarrow\) {{c5::signals represent changes in the auditory or visual intensity}}, e.g. {{c5::color changes}}

6. {{c6::Cognitive Vigilance Paradigm}}
\(\rightarrow\) {{c6::signals represent "information"}}, e.g. {{c6::proofreading a manuscript}}

State of the world vs. response in Signal Detection Theory:
{{c1::}}
{{c1::Sensitivity}} is the {{c2::resolution of the signal detection mechanism}} and refers to the {{c3::separation of noise and signal distributions}}.

Memory-based Design Guideline #1:
Organize information {{c1::into a small number of "chunks"}}.

Memory-based Design Guideline #2:
Try to create {{c1::short linear sequences of tasks}}.

Memory-based Design Guideline #3:
Use {{c1::persistence}}. Do not {{c1::flash important information onto the screen for brief time periods}}.

Memory-based Design Guideline #4:
Do not {{c1::"overwrite" the contents of working memory with additional tasks}}.

Memory-based Design Guideline #5:
Organize data fields to {{c1::match user expectations or input (e.g. automatic formatting for phone numbers)}}.

Memory-based Design Guideline #6:
Provide {{c1::reminders or warnings of the current state}}.

Memory-based Design Guideline #7:
Provide ongoing {{c1::feedback on what is happening}}.

Memory-based Design Guideline #8:
The user interface should behave in {{c1::consistent ways at all times}}.

Memory-based Design Guideline #9:
Terminology, icons and color should be {{c1::consistent between screens}}.

{{c1::Visual perception}} is the process of {{c2::extracting meaning from sensory information}}. It is concerned with {{c3::recognition and understanding}}.

{{c1::Vision}} is an easier process concerned with {{c2::detecting color, shapes or edges}}. Vision does not necessarily require {{c3::an understanding of the world surrounding us}}.
{{c1::Gestalt Laws}} are methods that the brain uses to {{c2::simplify recognition}}.

Gestalt Laws: Proximity
Objects that are {{c1::close in space or time}} tend to be {{c1::perceived together}}.

Gestalt Laws: Law of Good Gestalt / Simplicity / Pr√§gnanz
Complex figures are made sense of by {{c1::separating them into known, simple forms}}.

Gestalt Laws: Closure
Objects are perceived as {{c1::complete}} even if {{c1::there are gaps in the shape}}.

Gestalt Laws: Continuity
Objects are perceived as {{c1::continuous and smooth}} instead of {{c1::disjointed}}.

Gestalt Laws: Common Fate Principle
Objects that {{c1::"move" together}} are {{c1::related}}.

Gestalt Laws: Similarity
Similar figures tend to be {{c1::grouped together}}.

Gestalt Laws: Symmetry
Symmetry simplifies perception because {{c1::only one figure needs to be perceived}} and {{c1::others are just seen as symmetric multiplications}}.

Gestalt Laws: Part-Whole Relationship
The {{c1::same}} parts can create {{c1::different wholes}}.

Gestalt Laws: Area Principle
Objects with small areas tend to be seen as {{c1::figures}}, not the {{c1::ground}}.

Gestalt Laws: Surroundedness Principle
An area that is surrounded will be seen as a {{c1::figure}} and the area that surrounds it will be seen as the {{c1::ground}}.

Gestalt Laws: Common Region Principle
Objects located within the same {{c1::closed region}} are {{c1::chunked together}}.

Other principles of perception: Stimulus Intensity
The {{c1::intensity}} of a stimulus is perceived before the {{c1::meaning is processed}}.

Other principles of perception: Proportion
Proportions can represent {{c1::logical hierarchies}}.

Other principles of perception: Proportion (Golden Ratio)
The Golden Ratio expresses the relationship between {{c1::two aspects like width and height}}, which must be equal to {{c1::\(0.618\)}}.

Other principles of perception: Screen Complexity
Optimum usability is reached when the screen is {{c1::neither overly simple nor overly complex}}.

{{c1::Physical models}} can predict {{c2::efficiency based on the physical aspects of a design}}. For example, {{c3::Fitt's Law}} can be used to {{c4::estimate the best size and location of a screen object}}.
(Fitt's Law does not work well on touch interfaces due to, among others, the "fat finger problem")
{{c1::Hick's Law}} states that {{c2::the time needed to make a decision (e.g. a selection) is proportional to the log number of alternatives given}}.
{{c1::Mental models}} provide {{c2::a basic, low-resolution understanding of what is going on}}.
The {{c1::Gulf of Execution}} describes a {{c2::mismatch between the user's intentions and the allowable actions}}.
The {{c1::Gulf of Evaluation}} describes a {{c2::mismatch between the user's expectations and the system's representation}}.
A {{c1::Hierarchical Task Analysis}} is a {{c2::graphical representation of a task structure}}.
{{c1::GOMS (Goals, Operators, Methods, Selection Rules)}} is a tool for {{c2::Cognitive Load Analysis}}.
The {{c1::Keyboard Level Model (KLM)}} is a design tool that can capture and calculate {{c2::the physical actions a user will have to carry out}} to {{c2::complete specific tasks}}.
Contemporary GUIs are sometimes called {{c1::WIMP}} interfaces because they comprise {{c1::Windows, Icons, Menus and Pointers}}.
You want to run a PACT analysis. What does PACT mean?

> Paper & Pencil Analysis for Context and Technology
> Person, Action, Context, Technique
> People, Activity, Context, Technology
> Public-Actions-in-Context Technique
You have run a PACT analysis of the KVV website (public transportation). Give an example scenario (one sentence), in which you define P, A, C, and T. Mark the assignment to P, A, C and T.
A student (P) uses the KVV smartphone app (T) to find the fastest route (A) to his university (C)
Printed text is presented to a user to inform him about a problem. Into which part of the working memory will this information go? (one correct answer)
[Information] is displayed [to a user] in form of an icon. Into which part of the working memory will this information go? (one correct answer)
Which types of text font are suited for slides? (multiple answers) Also, is a justified text alignment ("Blockdarstellung") suitable for slides?

> Variable-Width Font
> Fix-Width Font
> Sans Serif Font
> Serif Font

> Yes / No
Name two phases of the reading process and explain them!

1.) Distinguish letter and word shapes

2.) Associate meaning
Name two eye movements that take place during reading and explain them!

Saccades: Quick, jerky movements, about 8-10 letters

Fixations: Intermittent pauses on areas of interest

Have a look at both figures. Consider the following scenario: A user is using a mouse on a desktop PC. He already pressed button 1 and now wants to move to button 2 to press it. The Movement Time (MT) in this example is:

> The MT is the same in both examples
> The MT of example 1 is about half of example 2
> The MT of example 2 is about half of example 1
> The MT of example 1 is about half of example 2 plus a factor \(a\)
> The MT of example 2 is about half of example 1 plus a factor \(a\)
> The MT of example 1 is logarithmically larger than of example 2
> The MT of example 2 is logarithmically larger than of example 1
> Cannot be said using Fitts' Law alone as button 1 is in the corner of the screen
Cannot be said using Fitts' Law alone as button 1 is in the corner of the screen
In the picture you see a command line as interaction style. Name two other styles!

Menu-Based Interface

Form Fill-In

Question and Answer

Direct Manipulation/Metaphors

Web Navigation

Three-Dimensional Environments

Zoomable Interface

Natural Language
Does the NASA-TLX provide subjective (not comparable between different participants) results or objective results?
Explain what happens in the second phase of the NASA-TLX test!

(First phase: Answer questionnaire, scores based on a 100 point scale with increments of 5)

Second phase: Perform 15 pair-wise comparisons to assess the weight for each of the measures (i.e. answer the question "Which factor is the more important contributor to work load for the task?")
Are higher NASA-TLX values always better (yes/no)? Explain!
No, the optimum workload has to be determined case by case to prevent over- and underload
What are triggers for sending out experience sampling questionnaires? How can we prevent a participant from receiving multiple experience sampling prompts within a short time frame?

Triggers: randomly, scheduled, at an event

Preventing short time frames: Use a scheduled approach or implement a cooldown time
You want to run a usability study using Cognitive Walkthrough. Which group of people do you invite to the study?

> A representative group of end users, as they will use the system
> Usability experts, as they are the best at exposing system weaknesses
> Friends, because only these give me honest feedback
> Students from campus, as they are easy to recruit
> None at all, because Cognitive Walkthrough does not require any people
Usability experts, as they are the best at exposing system weaknesses
Which information do you have to provide to persons in a Cognitive Walkthrough?
The experts have to know the assumptions about the user population, context of use and task details
What are the differences between results gained in a Think Aloud study and interviews?

Think Aloud: Inspective, free form, no active input from the interviewer during the process

Interviews: Retrospective, answer predetermined questions, possibly biased input from the interviewer
You conduct a survey through an unstructured interview. One of the interviewers is very rude, another very friendly against the interviewees. Does this affect the results?
What would be the consequences if answering a questionnaire was not anonymous? (one correct answer)

> Interviewees would be more precise in their answers, since they are perceived personally
> Interviewees would be inhibited in their answers, because they cannot anticipate consequences
> Interviewees would be more positive, as they hope for subsequent personal reward
Interviewees would be inhibited in their answers, because they cannot anticipate consequences
Name the three kinds of statistical data types that were introduced in the exercise! Name one example for each of these data types.

Effectivity - percentage of tasks successfully completed

Efficiency - time spent to complete a task

Satisfaction - rating scale for satisfaction

(Note: neither the lecture nor the exercise seem to mention "statistical data types" explicitely, so take this answer with a grain of salt)
Which condition need to be fulfilled so that a t-test can be applied to a sample of data?

The sample must be sampled randomly from a population of interest and the data variables must follow a normal distribution

(Note: neither the lecture nor the exercise seem to mention "t-tests" explicitely, so take this answer with a grain of salt)
What kind of correlation is measured by Pearson's correlation coefficient r and which values are possible?

The coefficient measures linear correlation and ranges from \(-1\) to \(1\)

(Note: neither the lecture nor the exercise seem to mention the "Pearson Correlation Coefficient" explicitely, so take this answer with a grain of salt)
Name the parts of the human working memory. Which kind of information is stored there?

Articulatory Loop, remembers short strings of words by rehearsing them repeatedly

Visuospatial Sketchpad, remembers visual information / images

Perform a chunking of the following phone number: \(004972160841709\).

Then perform an alternative chunking. Compare the two options regarding the possibility to remember the phone number.

Option 1.: \(004\ 972\ 160\ 841\ 709\)
Option 2.: \(00497216\ 0841709\)

Option 1. is easier to remember due to the smaller chunks representing more meaningful units

(Note: Many other chunkings are possible, e.g. chunking every individual number, which is also less helpful than Option 1.)
Describe the difference between recall and recognition.

Recall: Active memory search to retrieve a particular piece of information without another information to compare it to

Recognition: Searching the memory for a piece of information that matches given information, which is way easier than recalling

The figure below shows a screenshot of the KIT website. Name 3 Gestalt Laws which were applied here. Explain each shortly (about 1-2 sentences). To improve your explanation, mark parts of the figure with your pen.

Law of Common Region, applies e.g. to the "Schnelleinstieg" (white box)

Law of Similarity, applies e.g. to the green buttons at the top

Law of Proximity, applies e.g. to the articles and images at the bottom
What types of attention were introduced in the lecture? Shortly describe each of them.

Selective Attention: Willingly select focus

Focused Attention: Respond to external events

Divided Attention: Simultaneous focusing on different events
What is the relation between vigilance and attention?
Vigilance is an aspect of attention which refers to detecting a rare, unpredictable event or signal
What paradigms of vigilance did you get to know during the lecture? Name three of them and present an example for each one.

Free-response paradigm, e.g. power plant monitor supervision

Inspection paradigm, e.g. quality control

Successive vigilance paradigm, e.g. detect of a color is darker than the initial target

(Simultaneous vigilance paradigm, e.g. compare many types of garment to a standard piece of fabric)

(Sensory vigilance paradigm, e.g. color changes)

(Cognitive vigilance paradigm, e.g. proofreading a manuscript)

You want to evaluate your newly developed interactive system with a user study. You remember that depending on the method used, different memory systems are accessed. Assign the following methods (left) to the memory systems (right) by drawing a line between two dots.

Think Aloud - Working Memory

Questionnaires - Semantic (facts, meaning, concepts)

Interviews - Episodic (experiences and events)

Motion Logging - Procedural (motor skills)
You want to evaluate your icon design. Which memory process takes place when a user sees an icon he knows?
Which part of the memory does the process "rehearsal" access?

> Sensory memory
> Working memory
> Long-term memory

Long-term memory

(Note: might also be working memory, question is a bit vague)
What are the main features of Don Norman's consideration of affordance?
Name two of the three principles of Don Norman for designing user interfaces!

Make usable properties visible

Use natural associations

(Give feedback)
Which of these operating interfaces can Fitts' Law be applied to?

> Command line / text terminal without mouse
> WIMP interfaces
> Smartphone with touch screen
> Voice control (e.g. Alexa, Siri)
Name the three measurement classes to measure usability. Give one example for each measurement class.

Effectivity: Percentage of tasks successfully completed

Efficiency: Time to complete a task

Satisfaction: Rating scale for satisfaction
What are similarities and differences between Cognitive Walkthrough and Heuristic Evaluation?

Similarities: both work without actual users, are usually performed by experts

Differences: walkthroughs follow a specific scenario, heuristics give general rules of thumb
What is the Gulf of Execution?
The Gulf of Execution describes a mismatch between the user's intentions and the allowable actions
Name each EEAC EXECUTION step and apply them to the interface shown in the figure. Name the step at which a problem occurs.

Forming Intention: Wanting to go upwards

Specifying Action: Press up button (problem here: which one is up?)

Executing Action: Choosing and pressing the button
What is meant by Gulf of Evaluation?

> It is a lake of user interface evaluation capabilities based on the knowledge of Gestalt Laws
> It describes the amount of effort needed to interpret the state of the system and how well this can be compared to the intentions
> It describes the difference between the planned evaluation of a user interface and the actual execution of the evaluation according to PACT
It describes the amount of effort needed to interpret the state of the system and how well this can be compared to the intentions
For which mode of operation is the interface most suitable? Assign!

Command Line Interface - frequently repeating complex tasks

WIMP - complex tasks that need much explanation

Voice Control - tasks new for the user

> A particular person that you have observed in a user study
> An instrument for measuring the characteristics of a person
> A profile of an archetypical person in a domain
A profile of an archetypical person in a domain
Label the illustration with the missing three memory systems.

1.: Sensory Stores

2.: Working Memory

3.: Long-Term Memory
Fitts' Law can be used to determine the size and location of a screen object. Which 3 components does the law have?

Index of Difficulty (ID): Quantifies the difficulty of a task based on width and distance

Movement Time (MT): Quantifies the time it takes to complete a task based on the difficulty of the task and two empirically derived coefficients

Index of Performance (IP): Based on the relationship between the time it takes to perform a task and the relative difficulty of the task

> Execution/Exit Action Cycle
> Execution/Evaluation Action Cycle
> Execution Exit Analysis Cycle
> Execution Evaluation Analysis Cycle

In the design process, different types of scenarios are used: User Stories, Conceptual Scenarios, Concrete Scenarios and Use Cases. Assign the scenarios to their purpose by drawing a line between two dots.

User Stories - used for understanding what people do and what they want

Conceptual Scenarios - used for generating ideas and specifying requirements

Concrete Scenarios - used for prototyping ideas and evaluation

Use Cases - used for documentation and implementation
What are the steps to conduct an interview? Explain this briefly!

Introduction - introduce yourself, explain the goals, present consent form

Warm-Up - easy questions

Main Body - questions in logical order

Cool-Off - easy questions to defuse tension

Closure - thank interviewee, signal the end

The following table shows three methods that you can use in user studies: System Usability Scale (SUS), Think Aloud and measuring biometric parameters (e.g. heart rate). Please fill in the table to describe the methods. One response per cell is correct.

SUS: retrospective, subjective, qualitative, end user

Think Aloud: introspective, subjective, qualitative, end user

Biometric Parameters: introspective, objective, quantitative, end user

> Is based on a cyclic procedure
> Is closed and thus difficult to expand through further scenarios
> Serves mainly the formal representation of an HCI design process
> Includes requirements
> Does not require any documentation to not restrict creativity
> May contain parts of evaluation

Serves mainly the formal representation of an HCI design process

Includes requirements

May contain parts of evaluation
At which part of the scenario-based design are the descriptions for the system complete, that is, all system functionalities are covered with at least one scenario/story/case? (one correct answer)

> Concrete Scenarios
> Use Case
> Conceptual Scenarios
> User Stories
Which part of the scenario-based design can contain code? (one correct answer)

> Concrete Scenarios
> Use Case
> Conceptual Scenarios
> User Stories
Do conceptual scenarios already contain the technology to be used in a project?
Can Elicitation / Gathering for requirement analysis be part of a scenario-based design?
Can requirements be derived from user stories?
Do functional requirements specify the how-characteristics and qualities of a system?
Do functional requirements specify what a system does?
Do requirements include an implementation specification?
What does the MoSCoW prioritization mean with regard to requirements?

Must have: fundamental requirements without which the system will be useless/unworkable

Should have: would be essential if more time were available

Could have: of lesser importance, can be left out more easily

Want to have: will not have this time around, can wait
Which window arrangement is used for the smartphone app shown below?

In complexity analysis for visual design you were introduced to methods to calculate complexity. Can the complexity be influenced by selecting a variable-width or fixed-width font? (one correct answer) Please explain!

> A text block with a font of variable width is less complex
> A text block with a font of fixed width is less complex
> There is no difference in complexity
A text block with a font of variable width is less complex (due to decreased line length)
Complete the following graphic with parts of human memory.
From which part of memory is information recalled/recognized? Which process is faster?

Recall - long-term memory

Recognition - working memory

Recognition is generally faster
Interviews/Observation/Video/Focus Groups/Workshops are typically used in elicitation/gathering. Explain why.
They will identify artifacts used during the task (documents, forms, printouts, tools...) and provide additional insight which can be used further to generate User Studies

In order to obtain precise answers, you formulate the question very precisely in a questionnaire. Thus, the question and the sentences contained therein are longer than average sentences. The answers you receive are now...

> On average better, in the sense that they meet your question
> On average worse, in the sense that they do not meet your question
On average worse, in the sense that they do not meet your question (longer sentences always leave more room for interpretation)
When conducting a survey, you collect additional data about the user, e.g. gender, age, occupation etc. Does this make sense? (one correct answer)

> Yes, but only because I can then show statistically who participated
> No, because this is basically forbidden
> No, because I can not derive any further results from that data
> Yes, because with that data I can derive additional results
Yes, because with that data I can derive additional results
Study methods are to be selected for the collection of user stories. You can choose from... (two correct answers)

> SUS questionnaire
> Current Behaviour Study
> Proof of Concept Study
> Unstructured Interview
> Think Aloud
> NASA-TLX
In which task analysis methods is it possible to determine execution times? (two correct answers)
Can an HTA model be expanded successively, i.e. can you start with a rough structure of tasks and then add further sub-statements?
What are the smallest units in a GOMS description? Explain their properties using two examples.

Operators = Actions

Simple activities, e.g. pressing a button (no conscious mental effort) or reading a short exercise description

True or false?
1. Requirements can be derived only from User Stories
2. Requirements can be derived only from a Scenario-based design
3. Non-functional requirements specify the how-characteristics and qualities of a system
4. Non-functional requirements specify what a system does
Three-dimensional impressions can also be produced with two-dimensional effects. Name 3 and explain them!

Light and Shade

Linear Perspective

Motion Parallax (objects far away move slower)

Overlap

Relative Size

Texture Gradient (textured = closer)
Do humans have a consistent information taxonomy?
Which interaction style is particularly suitable for beginners? Set the following possibilities in descending order from very suitable to less suitable.
Wizard (very suitable) > Menu > Command Line (less suitable)
You are designing a form that should have exactly the same colors on the screen as on paper. Is that easily possible? Explain.

Not easily possible. The same impression can only be achieved under the same conditions, necessitating specific calibration. Reflective vs. self-illuminating displays use different color compositions and are perceived differently.
